title: Well Done!!!
comment: I had to think if this app is worth the third "!" in the title. Here's my story why. I finally got root on my phone and this update comes along. The issue I have is I really like having root but I'm obsessed with having the latest software version even the ones with just bug fixes. Who doesn’t love bug fixes? Sickos that’s who. As I sat there pondering the ramification of my decision a memory popped. "OTA..." something. A quick search of Play produces "OTA RootKeeper" OK, this sounds promising and it two steps above doing nothing. The first step above nothing is putting a sticker on your car for whatever issue you support just enough to deface your car for. Now in my case they would think I had an issue with "Oklahoma Turnpike Authority" which isn't too bad but I live in NY. I install the app, slam a few buttons and say good luck Maxine, yeah my phone is name Maxine. I couldn’t stand the wait for my update any longer and hit the install update. After the reboot I went Root Checker pro (yeah I liked it enough to go pro. Worth the buck) but alas root was gone. I was sad for moment but then I cheered myself up with the fact that the rooting community is populated with pretty good eggs

title: Stellar! Keeps root on my Verizon Galaxy S3
comment: At some point I found myself with Verizon pushing out an OTA update that no one had figured out how to root. This was my only option for keeping root access and it works beautifully. Install it and forget it! It keeps a backup copy of the SU binary and re-roots with a single click after an official OTA update. I've gone through three updates, the latest in late June 2013 to Android 4.1.2 vzw build VRBMF1 and it's worked every time. If you don't care about a custom MOD and just want to keep root access AND have official OTA updates, this is the ticket. Think of this as root insurance if your carrier pushes out an update and you lose root - just click and you're back in business!

title: Works - Tested on Galaxy Nexus 4.1.1. -> 4.1.2 OTA
comment: Just got the update notification on my phone, and this 100% worked. I'm on a rooted (stock Jellybean rom, locked bootloader) GSM Galaxy Nexus going from 4.1.1 to 4.1.2 OTA.   Directions (just incase anyone needs them); Download OTA RootKeeper. Open it. Allow root access. Hit 'Protect Root' Then go to Settings -> About Phone -> System Updates and update your phone. Wait for it to finish and your phone to turn back on. Open OTA RootKeeper. Hit 'Restore Root' Done. You can uninstall the app now if you wish, and just re-download it for the next update.

Instead of the su binary that only worked for apps that had already been authorised (with authorisation remembered), I ended up with no su binary at all!  I should've just used SuperUser to forcibly update... as it stands, it was easy enough to fix by re-flashing su.zip (then updating the binaries via SuperUser), but I thought OTA RootKeeper might have been a more elegant solution.

This lets me do a temporary un-root to use it, then I can re-root and go on with my life.  Also worked well with my latest Atrix 4G upgrade from 2.3.4 to 2.3.6 (Yep... no ICS release for me yet)... After the update, I lost root and this thing brought it back with a single tap!  LOVE IT!  MUST HAVE FOR ANYONE WHO WANTS TO KEEP ROOT ACCESS!

Droid X user here. This easily let me keep root during the latest (possibly last?) update for this phone. I wanted the update as it fixed several issues (like saving camera settings) but i also wanted to keep root to block certain apps, etc. This worked. Thank you

title: WARNING
comment: Any user of Voodoo OTA RootKeeper should remove the su backup before attempting a CWR restore of a nandroid backup or it will fail due to the nature of the protection. Clockwork recovery will delete (not format) everything on the system partition but error out upon reaching /system/su-backup. This will leave your device in an unbootable state.
